subject: RE: [junit] Re: limited access to data
msgSnippet: ... Some might think that your reply is a bit blunt, but it is actually a comfort knowing that I m not the only one that thinks this is a messed up
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Dave Astels [mailto:dave@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, July 29, 2003 3:51 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: limited access to data
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ostermueller, Erik"
> <erik.ostermueller@f...> wrote:
> > Hello, all.
> >
> > This post isn't necessarily JUnit related,
> > but it is very unit-testing related.
> >
> > With our legacy mainframe system,
> > it is not possible to add or
> > delete data on the fly (ie, from a unit test) -- you
> have to rely on
> > nightly batch processes for this.
> >
> > Since the unit tests can't set up and tear down
> > their own data, we're running into lots of snags.
>
> To quote Bob Martin: "So, what are you going to do about it?"
Some might think that your reply is a bit blunt, but it is
actually a comfort knowing that I'm not the only one that thinks
this is a messed up environment.

I get so frustrated sometimes that finding a different employer
sounds like a pretty reasonable option. I keep telling
people around here that testing w/o sufficient access to the data is
vastly more expensive. They don't seem to agree.
